meanings.definition: To prevent or constrain the development, expression, or action of something.
meanings.sent1: The strict rules stifled my creativity during the art class.
meanings.sent2: She stifled a yawn during the boring lecture.
meanings.sent3: The overprotective parent stifled their child's independence.
meanings.sent4: The thick fog stifled the view of the beautiful sunset.
meanings.sent5: The heavy workload stifled any chance of relaxation.

meanings.definition: To suppress or withhold a feeling or reaction.
meanings.sent1: He stifled his laughter at the inappropriate joke.
meanings.sent2: She stifled her anger and calmly explained the situation.
meanings.sent3: The comedian tried to stifle a giggle while performing on stage.
meanings.sent4: The student stifled his excitement when he received a perfect score.
meanings.sent5: The detective had to stifle his shock at the unexpected revelation.

meanings.sent1: The thick smoke stifled the firefighters' efforts to rescue the trapped family.
meanings.sent2: She felt like the heavy blanket was stifling her in the hot summer night.
meanings.sent3: The overprotective mother always worried she would stifle her child with too much care.
meanings.sent4: The oppressive heat seemed to stifle all life in the desert.
meanings.sent5: The lack of fresh air in the stuffy room stifled her breathing.
